title: Vols fall to Alabama
text:
Late touchdown gives Alabama ninth-straight win over the Vols Post to Facebook Vols fall to Alabama Late touchdown gives Alabama ninth-straight win over the Vols Check out this story on WBIR.com: http://on.wbir.com/1MZZbRF Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Vols fall to Alabama Tennessee coach Butch Jones and safety Brian Randolph react to a 19-14 loss to Alabama WBIR Matt Slovin, Tennessean 7:52 p.m. EDT October 24, 2015 Oct 24, 2015; Tuscaloosa, AL, USA; Tennessee Volunteers head coach Butch Jones walks off the following their 19-14 loss to the Alabama Crimson Tide at Bryant-Denny Stadium. Mandatory Credit: John David Mercer-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: John David Mercer, John David Mercer-USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
TUSCALOOSA, Ala. â€” After Alabama dominated its rivalry with Tennessee for the better part of a decade, the Vols finally looked as if they belonged on the same field as the Crimson Tide on Saturday. 
Tennessee put a scare into No. 8 Alabama that lasted deep into the fourth quarter, but the Crimson Tide held on for a ninth consecutive win in the series, 19-14. 
Alabama running back Derrick Henry scored with 2:24 remaining in the game to keep his team's College Football Playoff hopes alive and hand the Vols yet another narrow defeat. 
A game that began with the feel of a shootout quickly turned into a defensive struggle. The teams traded touchdowns on two of the game's first three drives, but Tennessee (3-4, 1-3 SEC) went until there were less than six minutes remaining in the game to score again. 
A four-play, 75-yard drive that spanned one minute and 15 seconds gave Tennessee a rare lead over Alabama (7-1, 4-1), but the Crimson Tide moved the ball on a tired defense to have the last word once again. 
Several times, the Vols looked poised to take the lead or tie the score only to come away with no points. Kicker Aaron Medley continued his disappointing sophomore season by missing a kick from 43 yards out and, twice, from 51 yards away. 
The 7-7 game stayed that way until halftime, but on the first Alabama drive after the break, quarterback Jake Coker hit his first four passes to bring the Crimson Tide to the Tennessee 1. 
There, the Vols' defense stood tall, stuffing Henry and then breaking up Coker's third-down pass attempt. 
Alabama settled for a field goal, which allowed the Vols to grab a one-point lead on Jalen Hurd's 12-yard fourth-quarter run. 
But Henry put the Crimson Tide back on top late, and Alabama held off the Vols on their final possession. 
Reach Matt Slovin at mslovin@tennessean.com or on Twitter @MattSlovin. Read or Share this story: http://on.wbir.com/1MZZbRF TOP VIDEOS
